pdhp1:0.2: Hail and Homage to all Buddhas, Dharmas and the Noble Saṅghas.
pdhp1:1: Mind precedes thoughts, mind is their chief, they are impelled by mind,
pdhp1:2: if with a base mind one speaks or acts,
pdhp1:3: through that, suffering follows him like a wheel follows the ox’s foot.
pdhp2:1: Mind precedes thoughts, mind is their chief, they are impelled by mind,
pdhp2:2: if with pure mind one speaks or acts,
pdhp2:3: through that, happiness follows him like a shadow which does not depart.
pdhp3:1: Here he laments, after death he laments, the wicked one laments in both places,
pdhp3:2: he laments, he suffers vexation, seeing the defilement of his own deeds.
pdhp4:1: Here he is happy, after death he is happy, the meritorious one is happy in both places,
pdhp4:2: he is happy… seeing the purity of his own deeds.
pdhp5:1: “He abused me, he struck at me, he overcame me, he robbed me,”
pdhp5:2: those who bear these ill-will their hatred is never appeased.
pdhp6:1: “He abused me, he struck at me, he overcame me, he robbed me,”
pdhp6:2: those who do not bear these ill-will their hatred is appeased.
pdhp7:1: Living contemplating what is pleasant, uncontrolled in sense faculties,
pdhp7:2: not knowing the limit in food, indolent, low in energy—
pdhp7:3: Māra surely overthrows that one, like wind overthrows a weak tree.
pdhp8:1: Living contemplating the unpleasant, well-controlled in sense faculties,
pdhp8:2: and knowing the limit in food, faithful, with energy aroused—
pdhp8:3: Māra does not overthrow that one, just as wind does not overthrow a mountain made of rock.
pdhp9:1: If you should find a prudent, wise companion, one who lives well, a wise one,
pdhp9:2: overcoming all your troubles you should live with that one, glad and mindful.
pdhp10:1: If you do not find a prudent, wise companion, one who lives well, a wise one,
pdhp10:2: like a king who abandons his conquered kingdom, one should live alone like a solitary elephant in the forest.
pdhp11:1: It is better to live alone, there can be no companionship with a fool,
pdhp11:2: one should live alone and not do anything bad, unconcerned like a solitary elephant in the forest.
pdhp12:1: He who, through desire, hatred, fear or delusion, transgresses Dhamma,
pdhp12:2: his fame diminishes, like the moon in the dark fortnight.
pdhp13:1: He who, through desire, hatred, fear or delusion, does not transgress Dhamma,
pdhp13:2: his fame increases, like the moon in the bright fortnight.

pdhp14:1: Heedfulness is the deathless state, heedlessness the state of the dead,
pdhp14:2: the heedful do not die, but those who are heedless are as if dead.
pdhp15:1: The wise, understanding this difference in regard to heedfulness,
pdhp15:2: rejoice in heedfulness, delight in the domain of the Noble Ones.
pdhp16:1: Those who meditate all the time, constant and firm in their effort,
pdhp16:2: those wise ones reach Nibbāna, the unsurpassed release from all bonds.
pdhp17:1: The foolish and stupid people cultivate heedlessness,
pdhp17:2: but the sagacious one guards heedfulness just as his greatest wealth.
pdhp18:1: Heedful amongst the heedless ones, wakeful amongst the ones who sleep,
pdhp18:2: like a swift horse who abandons a weak horse, the true sage moves on.
pdhp19:1: When the wise one eliminates heedlessness with his heedfulness,
pdhp19:2: and mounts the palace of wisdom, griefless, he looks on grieving people;
pdhp19:3: the wise one, like one standing on a mountain, looks down on the fools who are standing on the plains.
pdhp20:1: Whoever before was heedless, but later is not heedless,
pdhp20:2: that one shines brightly in this world like the moon released from a cloud.
pdhp21:1: Whoever before was heedless, but later is not heedless,
pdhp21:2: he, being mindful, can overcome clinging to the world.
pdhp22:1: A monastic who values heedfulness, seeing danger in heedlessness,
pdhp22:2: is unable to fall away: he is well-nigh to Nibbāna.
pdhp23:1: A monastic who values heedfulness, seeing danger in heedlessness,
pdhp23:2: advances like burning fire against the fetter, small or large.
pdhp24:1: You should delight in heedfulness, you should always protect your mind,
pdhp24:2: you should raise yourself from this pit like the tusker sunk in the mud.
pdhp25:1: Rejoicing in heedfulness, prudent, restrained in virtue,
pdhp25:2: in good time they attain that where, once attained, there is no grieving.
pdhp26:1: Do not rejoice in heedlessness, unacquainted with delight in sensual pleasure,
pdhp26:2: living in this way, ardent, with mind at peace, not proud,
pdhp26:3: devoted to mental calm, he will make an end to suffering.
pdhp27:1: One should strive, not be heedless, one should live by Dhamma, with good conduct,
pdhp27:2: living by Dhamma one lives at ease in this world and the next.
pdhp28:1: For he who is active, mindful, pure in deeds, considerate,
pdhp28:2: self-controlled, living by Dhamma, heedful, his fame increases.
pdhp29:1: Through activity, heedfulness, through self-control and through restraint,
pdhp29:2: the sage should make an island that no flood waters can overwhelm.
pdhp30:1: The one who has not energy at a time for energy, youthful, strong, lazy in his home,
pdhp30:2: whose mind lacks right intention and is indolent—the lazy one does not go along wisdom’s path.
pdhp31:1: One should not follow lowly things, one should not abide heedlessly,
pdhp31:2: one should not follow a wrong view, one should not foster worldliness.
pdhp32:1: One is not a Dhamma-bearer merely through speaking much,
pdhp32:2: but the one who, having heard a little, would see Dhamma for himself,
pdhp32:3: is one who bears Dhamma, the one who is not heedless regarding Dhamma.
pdhp33:1: Consider the Dhamma heedfully, do not let your mind swirl around in strands of desire,
pdhp33:2: do not, heedless, swallow a hot iron ball, and, while burning, cry: ‘This is suffering.’

pdhp34:1: Strive and cut off the thread, remove continuity, brahmin,
pdhp34:2: knowing the destruction of the conditioned, you are … brahmin
pdhp35:1: That one from whom one learned Dhamma, whether old or young,
pdhp35:2: with respect bow down to him, like a brahmin bows at fire-sacrifice.
pdhp36:1: That one from whom one learned Dhamma taught by the Perfect Sambuddha,
pdhp36:2: you should honor him, like a brahmin honors the fire-sacrifice.
pdhp37:1: Not because of matted hair, family or birth is one a true brahmin,
pdhp37:2: he who wards off wickedness, small or great, in every way,
pdhp37:3: through warding off wickedness, he is called a brahmin.
pdhp38:1: Like water on the lotus leaf, like a mustard seed on a needle,
pdhp38:2: he who is unsmeared by desires, that one I say is a brahmin.
pdhp39:1: The sun is radiant when it rises, the moon shines by night,
pdhp39:2: the accoutred noble is radiant, the meditating brahmin is radiant,
pdhp39:3: yet during every day and night the Buddha is radiant through his power.
pdhp40:1: For whom the near shore, the far shore or both do not exist,
pdhp40:2: free of fever, detached, that one I say is a brahmin.
pdhp41:1: When a brahmin has, through two things, crossed over,
pdhp41:2: then, for one who knows, all the fetters are laid to rest.
pdhp42:1: He who destroyed the fetter, destroyed conceit and continued existence,
pdhp42:2: living in the Community, standing by Dhamma, the knowing one does not approach society.
pdhp43:1: Whoever should speak a word of truth that is informed and is not coarse,
pdhp43:2: through which no one would be cursed, that one I say is a brahmin.
pdhp44:1: Whoever doesn’t mix with either householders or the houseless,
pdhp44:2: wandering homeless, with few desires, that one I say is a brahmin.
pdhp45:1: For whom there is no wrong-doing bodily, verbally or mentally,
pdhp45:2: being restrained in these three things, that one I say is a brahmin.
pdhp46:1: A brahmin should not hit a brahmin, nor should he abandon him,
pdhp46:2: woe to the one who strikes a brahmin, and to the one who does not abandon him.
pdhp47:1: Destroying mother first, and then two noble kings,
pdhp47:2: destroying a kingdom and its followers, the brahmin lives untroubled.
pdhp48:1: The deeply wise sagacious one, skilled in what is path and not path,
pdhp48:2: who has reached the ultimate good, that one I say is a brahmin.
pdhp49:1: The meditator sitting down, the one who is dustless, who has done his duty, without pollutants,
pdhp49:2: who has reached the ultimate good, that one I say is a brahmin.

pdhp50:1: Restraint is good everywhere, restraint is everywhere good,
pdhp50:2: a monastic who is restrained everywhere is liberated from all suffering.
pdhp51:1: Restraint of body is good, restraint of speech is good,
pdhp51:2: restraint of mind is also good, restraint is everywhere good,
pdhp51:3: a monastic who is restrained everywhere is liberated from all suffering.
pdhp52:1: One who controls his hands, controls his feet, controls his speech, controls the mind faculty,
pdhp52:2: with inner delight and composure, solitary, content: that one is called a monastic.
pdhp53:1: Calm in body and calm in mind, having calmness and composure,
pdhp53:2: having thrown off worldly gain the monastic is called one at peace.
pdhp54:1: That monastic who restrains the mouth, who speaks well, and who is modest,
pdhp54:2: who teaches the meaning of the Dhamma, his speech is sweet.
pdhp55:1: One should not despise one’s own gains, one should not live envious of others,
pdhp55:2: the monastic who is envious of others does not attain concentration.
pdhp56:1: Even if a monastic gains little he should not despise his gains,
pdhp56:2: even the very gods praise the one of pure life who is diligent.
pdhp57:1: Please bail out this boat, monastic, when bailed out it will go lightly,
pdhp57:2: cutting off passion and hatred, from here one will go to Nibbāna.
pdhp58:1: With uplifted mind, happy, having overcome what is dear and not dear,
pdhp58:2: then with lots of happiness, the monastic should wander mindfully.
pdhp59:1: That monastic who dwells in loving-kindness, with faith in Buddha’s dispensation,
pdhp59:2: has penetrated the state of peace, the joy in stilling of all conditions,
pdhp59:3: here and now there is Nibbāna, the unsurpassed release from all bonds.
pdhp60:1: For the one who has entered an empty place, a monastic with a peaceful mind,
pdhp60:2: there is superhuman delight from insight into true Dhamma.
pdhp61:1: Just as one with right mindfulness regarding the rise and fall of the components of mind and body
pdhp61:2: gains happiness in mind, this is the deathless state for the one who knows.
pdhp62:1: There is no concentration for one without wisdom, there is no wisdom for one without concentration,
pdhp62:2: that one in whom there is concentration and wisdom is indeed close to Nibbāna.
pdhp63:1: This is the very beginning for the wise monastic here:
pdhp63:2: contentment, guarding the senses, and restraint in the regulations.
pdhp64:1: One should resort to spiritual friends, ones of pure life, ones who are diligent,
pdhp64:2: one should be one of friendly disposition, one who will be skilful in conduct,
pdhp64:3: rejoicing frequently because of that, the monastic should wander mindfully.

pdhp65:1: Friends are good whenever need arises, at the break-up of life merit is good,
pdhp65:2: being content with everything is good, the abandoning of all wickedness is good.
pdhp66:1: Respecting one’s mother is good in the world, also respecting one’s father is good,
pdhp66:2: respecting ascetics is good in the world, also respecting true brahmins is good.
pdhp67:1: Virtuous conduct till old age is good, the establishing of faith is good,
pdhp67:2: speech that is beneficial is good, the destruction of conceit is good.
pdhp68:1: The arising of the Buddhas is good, the teaching of the Dhamma is good,
pdhp68:2: the harmony of the Saṅgha is good, devotion to harmony is good.
pdhp69:1: Meeting with the noble is pleasant, living with good people is pleasant,
pdhp69:2: through not meeting foolish people one will constantly be happy.
pdhp70:1: For he who consorts with fools grieves for a long time,
pdhp70:2: dwelling with fools is always suffering as it is with enemies,
pdhp70:3: the wise ones dwell happily as with an assembly of kin.
pdhp71:1: Therefore the firm and the learned, the virtuous, dutiful and noble—
pdhp71:2: follow such a true and intelligent person as the moon follows the course of the stars.
pdhp72:1: From love there arises grief, with love grief, with love fear,
pdhp72:2: for one who is free from love there is no grief, how is there fear?
pdhp73:1: Do not associate at any time with those who are loved or with those unloved,
pdhp73:2: there is suffering not meeting the loved one, and suffering from meeting the unloved one.
pdhp74:1: Therefore do not hold anything as loved, for speaking of the loved is loathsome.
pdhp74:2: There are no knots for those who hold nothing as loved or as unloved.
pdhp75:1: Hunger is the supreme sickness, conditions are the supreme suffering,
pdhp75:2: knowing this as it really is, know Nibbāna is the supreme good.
pdhp76:1: Health is the supreme gain, content the supreme wealth,
pdhp76:2: confidence the supreme kin, Nibbāna the supreme good.
pdhp77:1: If, by renouncing a small good, he might see a good that is large,
pdhp77:2: the wise one should renounce that small good, seeing the good that is extensive.
pdhp78:1: For a human who is always mindful, knowing the measure in food received,
pdhp78:2: his painful feelings become slight, he ages slowly, guarding his lifespan.
pdhp79:1: A person of good breed is rare, that one is not born everywhere,
pdhp79:2: wherever that hero is born, that family gains happiness.
pdhp80:1: There are surely true people everywhere, the good do not talk of desiring sense-pleasures;
pdhp80:2: when touched by pleasure or by suffering, true people are not elated or depressed.
pdhp81:1: The victor generates hatred, the defeated one finds suffering,
pdhp81:2: the one at peace lives happily, having abandoned victory and defeat.
pdhp82:1: Pleasant are rivers with good fords, pleasant is the person conquered by Dhamma,
pdhp82:2: the acquisition of faith is good, doing nothing wicked is good.
pdhp83:1: It is pleasant to meet the virtuous, it is pleasant to meet the learned,
pdhp83:2: it is pleasant to meet the Worthy Ones, who are free from attachments.

pdhp84:1: Whatever griefs or lamentations there are, and the many kinds of suffering in the world,
pdhp84:2: these all arise because of love, without loves, these do not originate.
pdhp85:1: Therefore they are happy and free from grief, who are without love for anything in the world,
pdhp85:2: therefore those wanting what is griefless, dust-free, should not have love for anything in the world.
pdhp86:1: For the one who has reached his goal, who grieves not, being released on all sides,
pdhp86:2: who has abandoned all the knots, no consuming fever is found.
pdhp87:1: For those who have no stores, those who comprehend food aright,
pdhp87:2: like the birds in the sky, their footprint is hard to find.
pdhp88:1: His mind is calm, his speech and his actions are also calm,
pdhp88:2: liberated by right knowledge, such a one is truly peaceful.
pdhp89:1: For the one whose senses are balanced, like horses well-trained by their charioteer,
pdhp89:2: who has abandoned conceit, who is without pollutants—even the gods envy such a one.
pdhp90:1: They lead one trained into a crowd, a king mounts one who has been trained,
pdhp90:2: amongst humans one trained is best, the one who can endure reproof.
pdhp91:1: Noble are the well-trained horses, the well-bred horses from Sindh,
pdhp91:2: and the great tusker elephants, and even more noble than that is the one who has trained himself.
pdhp92:1: Not by these vehicles can one reach that place,
pdhp92:2: as one through training himself well, being trained by the training, goes.
pdhp93:1: Just as solid rock is not shaken by the wind,
pdhp93:2: so the wise are not shaken by blame or praise.
pdhp94:1: The one who, while still impure, would wear the renunciant’s robe,
pdhp94:2: unendowed with restraint and truth, is not worthy of the renunciant’s robe.
pdhp95:1: The one who, steady in virtue, throws out any impurity,
pdhp95:2: endowed with restraint and truth, is indeed worthy of the renunciant’s robe.

pdhp96:1: Hasten to do wholesome deeds, ward off the mind from wickedness,
pdhp96:2: for the mind of the one slow in merit delights in wickedness.
pdhp97:1: Should a person do that which is wicked, he should not do it again and again,
pdhp97:2: let him not place his intention in it, for there is an accumulation of suffering for the wicked one.
pdhp98:1: If a person should make merit, he should do it again and again,
pdhp98:2: let him place his intention there, there is an increase of joy for the one who has made merit.
pdhp99:1: For the pure one there is always fasting, for the pure one there is always the fast day,
pdhp99:2: for the pure one, the one of clean deeds, his vow always succeeds.
pdhp100:1: Better undone is a wrong-doing, a wrong-doing one later regrets,
pdhp100:2: he grieves, thinking: “I have done a bad deed,” gone to a bad fate, he grieves much more.
pdhp101:1: Better done is what is well-done, which, when done, one does not regret
pdhp101:2: he is happy, thinking: “I have done a good deed,” gone to a good fate, he is happy much more.
pdhp102:1: Even the wicked one experiences good fortune while the wickedness does not ripen,
pdhp102:2: but when the wickedness ripens then the wicked one experiences wicked things.
pdhp103:1: Even the fortunate one experiences wickedness as long as the good fortune does not ripen,
pdhp103:2: but when the fortune ripens then the fortunate one experiences good fortune.
pdhp104:1: Even the wicked one does good while the wickedness does not ripen,
pdhp104:2: but when the time has gone by the wicked one experiences wicked things.
pdhp105:1: Even the fortunate one does wickedness as long as the good fortune does not ripen,
pdhp105:2: but when the time has gone by the fortunate one experiences good fortune.
pdhp106:1: If there is no wound for him in his hand he can carry poison with his hand,
pdhp106:2: poison does not enter without a wound, there is no wickedness for the one who does not do wrong.
pdhp107:1: A wicked deed that has been done, like milk, does not turn all at once,
pdhp107:2: smouldering, it follows the fool, like a fire covered with ashes.
pdhp108:1: A wicked deed that has been done, like a knife, does not cut all at once,
pdhp108:2: but when death comes he knows the destiny of those who do wickedness.
pdhp109:1: You should prepare beforehand what is to be done, do not tremble at what is to be done at the time for it,
pdhp109:2: for such a one who has prepared what is to be done, does not tremble at what is to be done at the time for it.
pdhp110:1: One should prepare to do that which one knows is for one’s welfare,
pdhp110:2: the sage, the wise one should make effort, not with the thinking of the charioteer.
pdhp111:1: As the charioteer who abandoned the smooth path of the highway,
pdhp111:2: and approached the rough path, then he broods, as upon a broken axle,
pdhp112:1: so the one departing from Dhamma and following what is not Dhamma,
pdhp112:2: when that fool comes to Death’s jaws he broods, as upon a broken axle.
pdhp113:1: Many wearing the monastic robe around their necks are wicked, unrestrained.
pdhp113:2: Wicked ones! Through your wicked deeds, you re-arise in the underworld.
pdhp114:1: One who speaks what is untrue goes to the underworld, he who says: ‘I do not do’ what he has done,
pdhp114:2: both of these are just the same when they have gone to the hereafter, they are humans who did base deeds.
pdhp115:1: He who offends against the inoffensive one, a purified and passionless person:
pdhp115:2: that wicked deed then returns to the fool, like fine dust that is thrown against the wind.
pdhp116:1: Like a merchant on a fearful path, with few friends and great wealth,
pdhp116:2: as one loving life would avoid poison, so should one avoid wicked deeds.
pdhp117:1: He who desires happiness for himself by causing suffering for another,
pdhp117:2: being associated thus with hatred, is not fully released from suffering.
pdhp118:1: The smell of a corpse is cut off eventually, also of one bloated when nights have passed,
pdhp118:2: but of the man who lives not by Dhamma day by day his smell is never cut off.
pdhp119:1: Just as householders having great treasures, when the city is on fire and burning,
pdhp119:2: because of their pearls, jewels, crystal and silver, make effort, thinking: “We will save something”,
pdhp120:1: so the ascetics of great wisdom, noble ones training along the noble path,
pdhp120:2: oppressed with the fear of birth, old age, death, afflicted by suffering, make effort, thinking: “We will attain peace”.

pdhp121:1: The fragrance of flowers goes not against the wind, nor does sandalwood or pinwheel or saffron,
pdhp121:2: but the fragrance of the good goes against the wind, the true person’s fragrance permeates all directions.
pdhp122:1: Sandalwood, pinwheel, then water lily and striped jasmine,
pdhp122:2: amongst these kinds of fragrance virtue’s fragrance is unsurpassed.
pdhp123:1: Pinwheel and sandalwood fragrance are insignificant,
pdhp123:2: but the fragrance of those who have virtue flutters supreme amongst the gods.
pdhp124:1: Māra cannot find the path of those endowed with virtue, who live heedfully,
pdhp124:2: and who are freed through right and deep knowledge.
pdhp125:1: Just like a beautiful flower, which has colour, but lacks fragrance,
pdhp125:2: so are well-spoken words fruitless for the one who acts not on them.
pdhp126:1: Just like a beautiful flower, which has colour, and has fragrance,
pdhp126:2: so are well-spoken words fruitful for the one who does act on them.
pdhp127:1: Just as a bee, without hurting the flower, its colour or scent,
pdhp127:2: gathers its nectar and escapes, so should the seer roam in the village.
pdhp128:1: Death takes up and carries away the one whose mind is attached to collecting flowers,
pdhp128:2: like a great flood carries off a sleeping village.
pdhp129:1: The End-Maker takes control of the one whose mind is attached to collecting flowers,
pdhp129:2: though he is unfulfilled with sense pleasures.
pdhp130:1: Just as from a heap of flowers one might make a lot of garlands,
pdhp130:2: so should many good deeds be done by one who is born a mortal.
pdhp131:1: Who will conquer this earth and the lower realm, together with the gods?
pdhp131:2: Who will win the well-taught verses of Dhamma as a good man wins a flower?
pdhp132:1: The trainee will conquer this earth and the lower realm, together with the gods.
pdhp132:2: He will win the well-taught verses of Dhamma as a good man wins a flower.
pdhp133:1: Just as striped jasmine casts off its (…) flowers,
pdhp133:2: so, monastics, cast off all passion and hatred.
pdhp134:1: Knowing that this world is just like froth, it has the nature of a mirage to those who understand,
pdhp134:2: cutting off Māra’s flower-tipped arrows, one should go beyond the King of Death’s sight.
pdhp135:1: Just as in a forsaken rubbish heap along the highway
pdhp135:2: a lotus might spring forth, with a pure fragrance, delighting the mind,
pdhp136:1: so amongst the forsaken, the Perfect Sambuddha’s disciple
pdhp136:2: outshines the blind and ordinary folk through his wisdom.

pdhp137:1: For a human who lives life heedlessly craving increases like a clinging creeper,
pdhp137:2: he rushes from one place to another like a monkey seeking fruit in the forest.
pdhp138:1: That one who is overcome by these low cravings in the world, which are difficult to get past,
pdhp138:2: for him griefs increase like grass that has been rained upon.
pdhp139:1: Whoever overcomes this low craving in the world, which is difficult to get past,
pdhp139:2: griefs roll from him like a drop of water on a lotus.
pdhp140:1: This I say to you: “Good luck to as many as have assembled here”,
pdhp140:2: dig up the root of craving, like one seeking the root digs up grass,
pdhp140:3: for one who has cut off the root of craving there are no griefs, how is there fear?
pdhp141:1: A man with craving as companion has a long time in births-and-deaths,
pdhp141:2: in this existence or another existence, here and there, again and again.
pdhp142:1: Having understood the danger, that craving is the origination of suffering,
pdhp142:2: free from craving, without attachment, the monastic should wander mindfully.
pdhp143:1: That bondage is not so strong say the wise, that is made of iron or wood or reeds,
pdhp143:2: impassioned and excited they seek out jewels and earrings and children and wives—
pdhp144:1: that bondage is strong say the wise, dragging down, subtle, hard to get free from,
pdhp144:2: having cut this down the good go peacefully seeking nothing, abandoning all suffering.
pdhp145:1: Not through a rain of coins is satisfaction found for sense desires,
pdhp145:2: the wise one knowing: “Sense pleasures have little joy, much suffering,”
pdhp146:1: does not find delight even in heavenly pleasures.
pdhp146:2: The disciple of the Perfect Sambuddha delights in craving’s destruction.
pdhp147:1: Without craving, without attachment, skilled in words and their explanation,
pdhp147:2: knowing how syllables are arranged, which come before and which after,
pdhp147:3: the one in his final body is said to be one of great wisdom.
pdhp148:1: There are flowing streams of affection and mental happinesses for a person,
pdhp148:2: pleasure-dependent they seek happiness, those people undergo birth and old age.
pdhp149:1: People surrounded by craving crawl round like a hare in a trap,
pdhp149:2: they are attached and clinging to fetters, they come back again and again to the womb for a long time.
pdhp150:1: Be free of the past, be free of the future, be free of the present, after crossing over all existence,
pdhp150:2: with mind liberated in every way, you will not return to birth and old age.
pdhp151:1: The one who is free from desires, who is free in the forest, though free from the forest, runs back to the forest,
pdhp151:2: come here and look at that person, though free, he runs back to bondage.
pdhp152:1: Fields are ruined by grassy weeds, these people are ruined by passion,
pdhp152:2: therefore there is great fruit for that given to those without passion.
pdhp153:1: Fields are ruined by grassy weeds, these people are ruined by hatred,
pdhp153:2: therefore there is great fruit for that given to those without hatred.
pdhp154:1: Fields are ruined by grassy weeds, these people are ruined by delusion,
pdhp154:2: therefore there is great fruit for that given to those without delusion.
pdhp155:1: The delightful wilderness wherein the people do not delight,
pdhp155:2: those without passion delight therein, but not those who seek sense pleasures.
pdhp156:1: Just as when the root remains firm and undamaged though the tree was cut down, it springs up again,
pdhp156:2: so when the tendency to craving is not rooted out this suffering appears again and again.

pdhp157:1: Lack of repetition is the ruin of the Vedā, a lack of maintenance is the ruin of homes,
pdhp157:2: indolence is the ruin of one’s appearance, heedlessness is the ruin of those on guard.
